I got the Muffaletta (marinated vegetables, olives, artichoke hearts and tuscan hummus on ciabatta) - YUM. Apparently this is a specialty in New Orleans? Delicious combination of flavors. 

I love that the menu incorporates Irish classics with rock solid other options (hey, some of us just aren't bangers and mash folks). Even if you've been to the downtown location it's worth a jaunt to the west side, laddies!

Nice irish pub in Madison. Had Shepard Pie. Fair. Service was fast. 

Great place for sharing time with friends.

Went here on a Friday night, wasn't too packed that it was hard to move around or find a seat. Just the right amount of people! Didn't come for food, just some good ol'fashioned drinking which I found to be quite expensive. Typical stocked bar and nothing extra special on tap, unless your totally in love with Irish beers.

In my opinion this place isn't anything special, especially being located on the square. Better off just bypassing.

This is a small plates place with an astounding view. I attended a business reception here and the staff were very good. We were able to use the more lounge space which was great and comfy for chatting. And the views. 

Food-ok I'm mostly vegan but will eat vegetarian when traveling. The breads with various toppings were good. The veggie pizza was excellent. No cheese, hummus and tasty and flavorful crust. Thigh veggie options were limited, still was nicely done. Reasonable cost. It's the ambiance that rates it with a forth star.

A case of incredibly bad service doomed our brunch at Brocach this morning. Nearly 40 minutes before our order was taken, and that's just the beginning. Had to ask multiple times for water, coffee was always, "still brewing", and everything just seemed to take extra long. Once the food was ready, they literally brought out two plates of food each trip to the table.  Maybe they should invest in some serving trays. 

Here's the odd part of the whole service issue, there were only 3 or 4 tables seated in the whole restaurant. Who knows. 

The food in general was fine. Our table of 4 adults and 2 kids had a variety, including the chocolate chip pancakes, a veggie omelet, the Irish breakfast, and I had the corned beef hash. The dry toast wasn't bad after we asked for jam. The hash, was really just corned beef chunks mixed with diced potato. Pretty simple mix it together prep, but still tasted good. 

Overall, I'll be in no hurry to return. Too many great restaurants in Madison.

Had the bangers and mash, which were stunningly delicious. The crispy outside of the sausages contrasted beautifully with the smooth potatoes. The apple shallot sauce and the crispy kale brought it all together amazingly. And, oh, I know it's trendy, but I could have scarfed a bunch more of that kale. A great way to add veggies to a traditionally starch heavy dish. 

Our waitress was friendly and helpful, making useful recommendations and there when we needed her. We went on a Saturday morning, so no crowds. I will definitely be back.

Went there on a Tuesday night and while place was empty, they sat us in booth towards the back next to the service bar and near the restrooms...sat for 10 minutes for a drink order, mind you the manager was sitting at the bar with her back to us just talking to bartender. Finally, the waiter gets there and we give him the full order (drinks+meals). Drinks and food came promptly...the Ruben was very tasty.  Overall food quality is good, however service was seriously lacking! Staff including manager should be more aware their guest!

Atmosphere and staff are fantastic, however their food is lacking. When Brocach first opened they had an excellent selection of meals. Their Irish Breakfast is no longer available. It was one of the better breakfast meals in the city. Their bangers and mash were delicious as well using proper bangers. They no longer use bangers, and instead just use some flavorless sausage. Bangers have a very specific flavor, and you cannot simply substitute them with anything else. Kind of a shame because I loved this place because of the proper UK food and flavors, and it now serves typical food you can get anywhere else.

Stopped in for brunch on a delightful Sunday morning. We elected outdoor seating to enjoy the weather despite the cramped space.  Drink and food orders were taken quickly. Everything else moved at a snails pace. The food, after it finally arrived, was the saving grace on this outing.  I would give the corned beef hash 3.5/5. Nothing outlandishly spectacular.  On the other hand, I am giving the donuts all of the stars. I could easily see myself going back for two orders and a coffee.

Looking back at our experience, I would have to heed the words of a passerby while we were eating.  "So this will be our choice 'B'." 

A solid "B" at that.

Let me start by saying... We went on the best night on the best day with the best weather. This place was awesome. Live irish music on fridays, phenomenal bangers and mash! The shepherds pie was pretty good. The sweet chili shrimp was yummy, but just as expensive as my entree, so I didn't think it was worth it. 

Overall, apps are way over priced, but the beer, irish dishes and atmosphere totally made the place. I drank a delicious snakebite. But the bangers and mash had this apple saute on top that blew my mind. GET THEM.

We miss the old Brocach. The new interior is sterile and nothing like an Irish pub - it looks like any other generic hipster restaurant now. The new menu is meh. My husband had the beef pot pie - for $14 the serving was small and there wasn't a ton of beef in there. I had just a side of Mac n cheese because nothing was sounding terribly appetizing. The mac n cheese was tasty, and for $4 I got a good size portion. My friend got the bangers and mash - she was disappointed they had changed the recipe because it used to be one of her favorite dishes. 

Overall, the service was great. The food was okay, the drink menu was small and the decor was disappointing. If this was my first time here, I'd probably give it a better rating. But knowing what it used to be, I can't give it more than a 2. We won't be back.

I've been here for brunch and dinner many times and love the food! 

A lot of the good restaurants on the square have crazy waits for brunch, yet for some reason it seems like people don't know about Brocach. Take advantage of this and eat their delicious food without waiting! There's traditional Irish fare as well as the typical stuff. I've really enjoyed the bangers and mash, Ruben breakfast burrito and the biscuit and sausage gravy.


This is also a fun bar. Good drinks and friendly bartenders. I like the tavern decor, kind of feels like you're in a home or an old school inn.
Came here for fun and was not disappointed. Sam was excellent and the service was amazing. I would highly recommend this place to anyone looking to have a great Irish Pub experience!!!

Has anyone ever been to an irish bar that didn't seem priced beyond what it should be?  What is it about "irish bistro" that warrants doubling prices?    I mean, its meat, potatoes, and cabbage....seemingly always for $12 and up, washed down with a $6 and up beer.  I'm not even too sure there is a defining "irish" thing about the the irish bars except for a little more woodworking and high prices.

Disclaimer: I rarely like irish bars, in case you couldn't tell from the above.

Disclaimer aside, brocach is actually one of the better "irish bistros."  Food is decent, but not worth what it'll cost you.  Has a decent irish beer selection, but it's probably also not worth what it'll cost you.  Especially when you can get the same beers elsewhere for less.

Nothing has really stood out to me that I've eaten.

Was shocked when I walked into this place after it being a few years. They had renovated the place, changed the menu and the beer selection (they have a "take over" of other breweries for limited events and they had no porter/dark beer selection besides the typical Guinness on tap), and also the recipes to some of their traditional dishes (fish and chips is what I had.) Was disappointed to not see the old booths, snug corners for great people watching on the Square, and the loss of great food.  The fish and chips came out smaller, oiler, less breaded (I was ok with that), but the fries were soggy with oil.  Place was very empty for a Friday afternoon; it usually is teeming with people coming off from working the capital and college kids but this is summer.  Sadly I don't think I will return to one of my favorite places. Service was good and attentive, music wasn't too loud and played 90s rock alternative, and there was some people to watch but it's not enough for me to want to return.  Cooper's Tavern is where I'm heading for my Irish food kick on the Capital Square.

A fun place to hang out, especially when the bars further down State Street are crawling with students.  Good beer selection and pretty decent food.  Oh, and Brocach has the most amazing black bean burger I've ever tasted.  Seriously.  I don't care if you're normally a carnivore, order the black bean burger and cherish every bite.

Just an ok experience

It was a frigid Saturday in November, noonish, so we came in and ordered hot toddies. After a bit of a wait they only brought 1. Rather than order another we split it. Ordered bloody marys spiked with Guinness and a beer back. We got both this time but they weren't anything special. They may deserve a higher rank on a normal day but our visit fell on 2.5 stars unfortunately.

This would have been a 3 or 4 star rating but the 25+ minutes we were there after we were done eating just waiting to pay was too annoying. I could have dealt with it if we were finishing up drinks or something but we were just sitting there and waiting and waiting and waiting. The service when we first got there was pretty quick but it soon took a dive. 

Husband and I each had a bourbon old fashioned. It was tasty but there were chunks of sugar not dissolved that kept plugging the straws. Good to know it's made properly though. Had a decent beer selection, nothing extraordinary. 

I had the fish and chips which were really good. The tartar sauce was yummy. I would have liked fewer chips and maybe one more piece of fish. Husband had the bangers and mash and he said it was good. The menu is pretty minimal but a good variety of items. 

Overall, I don't think we would go again for a meal. Maybe would stop for a drink, but not likely with so many better options in the area.

Update: I was on the fence about giving a 2 or 3 star rating. After I gave it a 2, I was contacted by a gentleman from Brocach asking questions about my review and he said service is something they've acknowledged as being something they need to improve. I'm upgrading this review from a 2 to a 3 and I would be willing to try it again in a few months to see if there has been improvement. Thanks for reaching out and I'm glad to hear you are working on improving. Maybe we'll stop in again.

This is big step above regular bar food. There are many healthy options on the menu. I have enjoyed the shepherds pie, the salads, soups and the chicken dumplings.  The selection of beers is diverse and the choices they have made for their offers excellent.
As with many folks, we found the food good.  It is the service that is slow.  I had the wild mushroom shepherd's pie.  Very hearty meal with a great flavor.
Very cool Irish Pub atmosphere.  In fact, probably one of the best irish pubs in Madison.  I've been here for lunch and occasional happy hour after work and never been disappointed.

Old Fashion was the non-dive go to bar of 08. For 09, I'm choosing Brocach. 

Tuesday night in January was empty, but the emptiness has its nice side. I got to explore everywhere in the bar without hesitation. This place is beautifully constructed. Love the sofas, and booth throughout the bar. Nice. I can appreciate the grown-up sophistication while sipping on French 75.

Ladies, if you have to go to the rest room, go to the 1st floor's. The upstairs' door doesn't clothes completely. Unless you are a fervent fan of 1920 deco, I'll stick to the pretty, auto-flushed down stairs one.  

I want to try the food next time with a pint of Guiness.

WORST BRUNCH IN MADISON!!!!! See my picture!

Seriously disappointing brunch, I got the breakfast sandwich and it was a complete disgrace to food and restaurants around the downtown area. 

The sandwich itself was comical, my friends and I could not stop laughing at how seriously sad it looked. Rather than cheddar cheese as the menu lists, it contained a few unmelted slices of kraft American singles....I seriously urge you to check the picture I uploaded to see this monstrosity.  The bacon was anemic looking and slightly undercooked and the bread was a joke, it looked and felt like it was microwaved - untoasted completely but slightly warm. The menu also listed a Dijon mayo for the sandwich which was no where to be found. The egg was ok I guess? It honestly felt like a cook ran out of cheese and decided hitting up Walgreens for a pack of kraft singles was a good idea. 

One of my group members got the French Toast and it was just two small slices of a baguette. Not thick cuts or anything, we thought it may have been a joke when we saw the two small pieces of bread, but alas it was reality. Not only was there an abysmally minuscule amount of French toast, it was bland and lacking flavor.

My friend asked if we could speak to a manager but apparently they were busy on a call. They ended up comping her orange juice...again it made no sense but at least it was comical.

I eat out around Madison 4-5 times a week and this is the first time I have just been completely shocked by food lacking in quality. I seriously urge you to save your money or try any other place, heck even the subway next door is better.
Very nice staff and reasonable variety of menu.  I dream about their beet salad - SO good!

Well decorated Irish Pub.  Looks like a great place to have a beer or whiskey, but I was a little let down with my meal.

I ordered a bowl of potato leek soup and a classic Reuben w/fries.  The soup was a major let down.  Very watery, with no potato flavor.  Not only was the soup plain, it came out right before on sandwich.  Like one spoonful of soup, and bang... Here's your sandwich.  

Two other things surprised me, no salt/pepper on the tables, and that they do not have any thousand island dressing.  No dressing available for a Reuben?  

As far as my sandwich, I would say that that was very good.  Would have been excellent with a little 1000 Island!  Fries were good too.

We started on the square at the Old Fashioned. There was an hour wait there for 5 people. We were hungry and it was hot out, so we ventured over to Brocach to see if there was a wait for a table. No wait and they had AC- so that was a bonus for us! They get 2 stars for the AC. The food took forever and it wasn't very good. The fish fry was disgusting. the batter on the fish was soggy and FULL of oil. YUCK! My fries were so charred that they almost disintegrated as I chewed them. I had the worst stomach ache (almost instantly) from the food. I had to put my best face on since we were hosting a guest to dinner. We had ordered cheese curds for a starter and no one wanted to eat more than one. Cheese curds people! You HAVE to get these right in Wisconsin! If there are any left on the plate, this is a very bad sign. I don't think I have ever heard of that happening. 
.

I came for the Guinness on tap. And while here, learned about the "peatiness" of Scotch and had some very edifying conversations with customers who come here for their depth of brew as well as their knowledge. A great place to enjoy a Guinness and a shot of your favorite spirit: classy, without the bullshit attitude!

I had another patron physically assault me while I was dancing with the Slainte dancers on St. Patrick's Day and the front of house team immediately informed the Manager after I spoke with them and the individual was removed. I thoroughly appreciate the team's actions to make other patrons feel comfortable and safe in their establishment. I will lost definitely return.

I met a couple folks here after dinner to watch a game. Although the crowd is much older than what I'm used to at the other establishments around the capitol, it was a nice reprieve from the college bar scene.

I wasn't in the mood for a beer, but they did have a delicious pineapple infused vodka sitting in a water dispenser on the bar that caught my eye. Get it on the rocks or in a martini, either way, there is more than enough pineapple juice to cut the taste of vodka. Dangerous.
Brocach has earned the extra star mostly due to ALWAYS fantastic service, excellent drinks, and the perfect setting for my department's Christmas party.  The food was fantastic!

I was visiting family in Madison last week and my daughter and I went out to dinner.  Downtown Madison is busy on a Saturday night and it's difficult to get into a decent restaurant without a wait.  We decided to try this restaurant because it wasn't overly busy.  I visited Ireland for two weeks last summer and have a pretty fair idea of what a good pub is like.  I don't know whether this one was or not because we were seated in what I can only describe as a cubbyhole.  Walls on three sides.  My daughter's view was me and the wall behind me.  My view was of people going to and from the restrooms right around the corner.  Our appetizer was brought to us with our entrees.  I don't know how any restaurant in Wisconsin could mess up cheese curds but Brocach managed it.  They tasted like they were frozen then deep-fried.  The Shepherd's Pie I had was....adequate.  Nothing special.  The only highlight was the dessert of Blueberry Bread Pudding with ice cream that was a very generous portion and tasty.  This is not a place I will revisit.

I went to Brocach with a friend for lunch on a Thursday afternoon, and it was great! The atmosphere was inviting and warm, and created an idea of what the style of the restaurant was like immediately. The restaurant wasn't crowded, so we sat down right away, and our waiter was friendly and prompt. We both loved our wraps and sandwiches, I will definitely head back!

Great place any time, but especially for happy hour. Burger or pork sliders are fabulous and adding 12 wings is the topper. The drink specials are great and are a super time to try higher end whiskey or Scotch, not to mention a good old Murphy's stout.
Over priced food/drinks and we were seated at a table that was literally in the hallway to the restrooms when there were other open tables. Not again.

This place can only get away with their slow service and lackluster menu because of the location. 

When we visited in May, we were quickly seated and brought drinks. Then, the waiter never came back to take our order... Until an hour later. By that time, the two menu items we really wanted had run "out" (how do you run out of bangers and mash? I thought the dish originated from scarcity?). So, we ordered a lobster roll with a side of Mac n cheese.

But it gets worse. After two hours waiting for our food, it arrived. But, the chef got our order completely wrong. We got a side of fries instead of Mac n cheese. After all that trouble and wait we were hoping to at least get what we were promised. The waiter was kind and empathetic. He checked, but the kitchen refused to make us Mac n cheese. So much for customer service.

Then, we were promised that the kitchen would give us our sinner "on the house". Okay, great - a silver lining in this mess. Well, unfortunately when the check came, nothing was comped except the Mac and cheese which DID NOT EVEN COME to our table. So, we ended up not having to pay for food we never ate, but paid full price for everything else. We left with a very unhappy crew. 

Horrible experience, horrible dining service, pathetic menu.

Casual Irish pub. Creative seating options ( booths, a snug, bar, communal and individual tables). We were there on trivia night which was fun. Food choices were good and solid. Delicious salads. Several vegetarian and gluten free options. Friendly waitstaff. Daily specials. Tons of beers. Worth a visit when you are here to shop or go to a Badger game.
Not friendly.  It was not busy yet the service was extremely slow.  Our group group did not feel welcome.
Love the live Irish music and the apps are great. Lots of food for the price. Just wish they added Killian's to the beer list.

The family and I decided on a quick trip to Madison to check out the Capitol building and the Children's Museum. We wanted to grab a bite and decided on Brocach.  We were delighted to see it wasn't crowded as we have a daughter on the Autism spectrum and is adverse to extremely loud places.  We figured that the timing may have had something to do with is since we got there about 2pm.

The service was ok. Our waitress was really friendly but didn't really understand the menu it seemed. When I asked how many sausages you get as a side, she didn't know. When we asked about the fruit, she said you get strawberries but they didn't have any. I can see some of these being honest mistakes but I would also expect the wait staff to have a good handle on the menu.

The food was not anything we would go back for. My wife said the blood sausage was disgusting and the banger I had was weird... maybe that's just the style? She felt a little ill after eating as well... we won't blame it on the food but...

The highlight of the day was probably the pint of Guinness my wife had. 

We would not be coming back here and cannot recommend anyone else go either. There are a ton of restaurants in the area and hopefully what we experienced was the norm for the restaurants near the Capitol.

Cozy atmosphere in a neighborhood with a lot going on!  I've eaten here several times and the food is solid, the staff great, and the manager is wonderful. I had the Ruben sandwich on my last visit and it was so chewy I had to send it back which is rare for me. They let me order something new and promptly got it to the table and gave me half off the mushroom Swiss burger I ordered (super yummy btw-the bun was especially amazing) since my first choice was sub-par. I realized today I had forgotten my check card and when I called they were quick to check for me and had it waiting when I picked it up. I couldn't ask for more and I will definitely be back to enjoy the atmosphere with my friends and the live Irish style music!

"Garbage baked into my daughter's Sheppard Pie"  

My daughters and husband had lunch at the Monroe Street location for a birthday celebration. After eating half of her Sheppard Pie, my daughter noticed a plastic cup (with ketchup in it) INSIDE her dish- as in cooked into it. Yes, I'm gagging as I wrote that. When she told the waiter he was shocked about it and made her a new one, to go --as everyone was done eating by then. The "to go" version was also odd- extra mushy and missing ingredients?? (Of course my daughter had totally lost her appetite anyway). I followed up with several calls asking for a refund for a horrible dining experience and spoke with three people who said I needed to talk to the manager. I was called back one time- rude , short message and that's it, no number left. I tried to call back again several times, no answer--then one more curt message left for me but clearly no attempt to address the situation so- just letting the world know there was GARBAGE BAKED INTO MY DAUGHTERS SHEPPARD PIE and all we asked for was a refund- nope didn't even get decent customer service after such an unacceptable mistake.

I walked in and heard Joy Division playing on the radio. To hear my theme music made me instantly love this place. Great food and ambiance.
Decent beer selection and delicious brunch selections.
We will be back!
Great atmosphere reminiscent of an Irish Tavern with traditional Irish food nicely presented in good size portions at a moderate price

Had a late dinner here friday night... it was alright. The atmosphere was pretty lively, with lots of dressed-up young ladies, gangs of dudes, bachelorette parties, and the like. Husband and I got two salmon dishes - BBQ salmon salad and a grilled salmon entree. Sad to say, we should have ordered two salads - it was about $5 cheaper and far more satisfying. I have a problem with dishes that don't warrant their price, and I definitely felt the salmon entree suffered from this condition. The sweet potatoes were fine, not noticeably sage-roasted, and the apple slaw was minimal and without dressing. The salmon salad was bountiful with a surprisingly spicy vinaigrette. The service was mostly inattentive. My noble rogue cocktail was the highlight of the meal.

The ambiance is Ireland-touristy rather than authentic Irish pub, if you've been lured into Bunratty Castle soon after landing in Shannon Airport, you know what I mean.  We came here after being discouraged by the disorganized looking long wait at a very nearby highly rated breakfast place one Sunday morning after checking out of the Madison Concourse.  This place had no wait (Sunday morning at 11) which raised suspicions, but I had high hopes for Irish breakfast.  Then I saw that they have poutine!  If you've never had poutine, it's a Canadian way of getting high cholesterol and dying early.  I wouldn't even know what poutine is if it weren't for Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto's antics, but now that I do know, I prefer my poutine without cocaine.  Here, they serve it with their Hollandaise sauce, which isn't quite right, ask to substitute their brown mushroom gravy instead, and that is the best way to undo any healthy diet you may be trying.  The Chief of Staff tried their biscuits and gravy which was okay, I think the way to go here is poutine plus Guinness on draught (is there really any other way?).  Service was good, really much better than what we saw around the corner at the top rated brunch place, next weekend morning we're in Madison, we're coming back here.

Since remodel, I would not recommend. I specifically made a stop here while in town for my birthday for my all time favorite drink, the stoli doli, only to be informed that they were no longer going to be serving them. I used to love coming to this place - it had a great vibe, now it just feels sterile - with no stoli dolis to boot! Anything that was special about this bar was completely stripped away. Now it's just like any other white washed sports bar you'd find in suburbia - without stoli dolis.

In full disclosure, I have been boycotting this place since they botched my wedding rehearsal party 2.5 years ago. A bride never forgets.

However, I was forced back there this week with co-workers. I was seated in a booth with an enormous hole in the center (think toilet). The black bean sliders were bland and mushy, served on a dry bun (guacamole was promised, but not delivered), with the tiniest shred of rubbery cheese on top. Two of us ordered this and both of us agreed - never again. I tried a bite of the truffle fries and they were pretty good. Although, I would eat cardboard if you drizzled enough truffle oil on it. The Guinness is solid, for America.  

The kicker. They inquired about whether they could seat another party in our booth - like, with us. It took everyone by surprise but me, since that was the same thing did for my wedding rehearsal dinner. Two parties in the same room.  But that time they didn't ask.
brocach means "badger hole"  so that's what we'll call it.  the chicken is excellent.  its the only thing i've ever had there.  they don't have beamish.

Loved this place before, now that it's all redone, I'm a little concerned. It seems like there was absolutely no staff training, and if there was they don't care about customer service at all. We sat at the bar, wanted to get a couple appetizers with drinks and the bartender didn't give us menus or water without us asking for them... because he said "it's hard to tell who comes and goes." Which, understandable, but it wasn't busy. Then we asked how the smoked salmon came, wondering if we should share it, the bartender said "I'm not sure, we're new so I don't know" then turned around and walked away, without asking anyone or coming back to us with an answer.. he wasn't wearing black so I'm guessing he was a manager, which seems odd to be a manager and be that rude to your customers and basically ignore them. He also asked us if we were done at the end, I said "yes" and he didn't bring us the check, we had to wait for him to come back to us after 15 minutes to ask for it. Now I love Broach, but having the bartender walk around with a giant ego, and not care about the customers or the menu at all does not work well for the new appearance of the restaurant. Sad.

Went here to meet a friend for a few drinks and apps. I went in to ask the host to put me at a table outside. After that, I was not acknowledged for almost 20 minutes. I checked how much time had elapsed- to make sure I wasn't tripping. For real- no "hello", "be right with you", not even a glass of water or menus. I watched other outdoor patrons being helped and chatted with while I was not even given a glance. I saw lots of scurrying and wasted motion, which gave the clear impression of a very scattered and inefficient staff.  Finally, a server seemed to notice me. I do not fault her- she was really nice, actually. I think the place is just not run well, and the staff reflects that confusion.

I had a cup of clam chowder that tasted like it was from a can and a very bland and inadequately boozy Bloody Mary. Soon after, my friend showed up and had one drink. He had a Bucky Book coupon for a "special entree"- none of which appealed to him, so he didn't have anything. A vodka tonic was what he ended up having. The other food I've had there has been bland and overpriced. The Scotch eggs are alright, but they are TINY. If not for my friend's suggestion, I wouldn't have considered going there. I usually refer to Brocach as Irish Disney Land. That about sums this place up...

When I first walked in, I was like like... whoa. This is terrible.

Basically, this place used to be like an actual Irish pub with lots of dark wood, low lighting, and squishy booths. Totally my kind of place. Now it is a start white industrial hipster hangout with the worst scary bright lights and it is SO loud.

I was not pleased. I used to love this place. It was one of my favorite spots downtown because of the chill ambiance and pub-like interior. They totally ruined all of that. I wish they would have kept it how it was.

However, onto the positive. I ordered a strip steak and it was absolutely fantastic. Cooked perfectly. The brussel sprouts it came with were absolutely delicious and the mashed potatoes were on point. The two people I was with both ordered the fish fry which they said was excellent. Honestly some of the best food I've had at a restaurant in awhile. A little pricey but I'd say it's mostly worth it. If the inside and atmosphere wasn't so terrible, I would have given this a strong five stars.

Also, our waitress was lovely and even though she was very busy, she was attentive and kind.

I definitely suggest eating here, but not at a busy time unless you want to be screaming at whoever you're with to have a conversation. Also, wear make up because that lighting isn't doing anyone any favors.

We visited Brocach for dinner during their recent restaurant week.

First the good.  It was easy to get a reservation and were seated immediately when we arrived. Our server was friendly and checked on us at appropriate intervals throughout the meal. When it was obvious one member of our party was not enjoying her dessert the server offered to bring her another choice. The location is great and the atmosphere sets the mood well. 

Unfortunately the food was underwhelming to say the least. Appetizers were disappointing - the beer and cheese flavors overwhelmed the mussels, and the bread served with them was so crisp as to be useless sopping up the broth. The salad was OK but included tasteless canned beets which would have been better left out. 

I was having trouble deciding between two entrees and asked the server for a recommendation. The sweet potato crusted whitefish she recommended was bland and lackluster. I honestly don't know why anyone would recommend it, other than that they were told to push it. The accompanying risotto was creamy but again tasteless.  Both I and one of the other people I was dining with doused fish & risotto in the vinaigrette to make them edible.

Our other dining companion had the lamb roast, which was much better.  For dessert, the bread pudding was good, but the creme brulee was a disaster. The sugar was so thick that the top was burnt and the bottom layer was still unmelted crystals while the "creme" was a watery consistency that was wholly unappetizing. 

Overall, the food did not live up to expectations and I would not return.

Sunday brunch turned into a chaotic meal. There were only two tables occupied so we thought we'd have good service. However, the waitress was very inattentive and service was slow. We ordered potato leek soup and they brought us chili instead, stating they were out of the other soup. My salad was missing all of the ingredients except the lettuce. It had to be sent back for cheese, walnuts, and cranberries to be added. The corned beef hash we ordered was very good. The bill was a mess and had to be fixed 3 times to finally get it correct. We would have been significantly overcharged if we didn't speak up. When I told the waitress what the prices were in the menu, she argued with me but then looked and realized the price I told her was the right one.

We've gone to the Brocach on the Square a few times, loving it at first and then being let down a few times. It's been okay, but we stopped saying, "Oh! Let's go to Brocach!" Today, we found ourselves in front of a closed Trader Joe's for Easter, so we decided to get dinner instead, and Brocach was the only place open.

We kind of trudged in and waltzed out! The food was great here. I loved the decor -- the high tables and big booths were so luxurious.

First I got a cup of the vegetarian potato leek soup, which was lovely. Derek got the rosemary and salt wings which he devoured. 

The mac n cheese sounded great, but it had kielbasa in it so I decided to try something else (though the waitress said that it's super easy to take it off). Derek got the mac n cheese instead. IT WAS SO GOOD. I am used to restaurant mac n cheese getting lazy and using the presence of a really creamy-looking dish in place of something that actually tastes good. Or, adding bread crumbs on top of a pile of bland as hell dish and calling it gourmet. This dish looked completely unassuming, but the flavors were fantastic. We kept taking another bite and another bite! Ugh, yum.

I had the walnut burger which is vegetarian and had artichoke on top of it. It had cheese or a sauce, I can't remember, and some mixed greens. With the onion bun, so many great flavors were in my mouth. Happy camper 100%.

I think next time we want Brocach, we'll head to the Monroe Street location!

We just went for brunch again today ... and sad to say, we were disappointed. :( Maybe it's because the first two times were such a success?

Mostly we wanted to point out that the $3 side of asparagus was extremely disappointed, laughable, and totally overpriced. It tasted okay but I assure you, you can do the same thing at home with an oven and some olive oil. They gave us about 6 pieces and just threw them on a plate without any thought for presentation. I felt quite cheated -- it should've been a dollar at the MOST. Boo.

Great cocktails, comfortable atmosphere, tasty food.

I've always enjoyed the Brocach, and feel the new look helps set them apart from some of the others around the square.  The menu has just enough selection to make a night enjoying a few drinks feel comfortable without getting overwhelmed with choices.  One of my top picks for warming up on a cold winter evening or meeting friends downtown.

This place is terrible since the remodel. Certainly not an Irish pub anymore.  This place used to be a wonderful place to get quality liquor and delicious Irish food. On occasion you would catch an Irish band jamming out.  It was a perfect place to take a date, for a cozy nook.  

After the remodel, blah, no different then any of the other sterile overpriced pretentious club environments downtown.  This place has no life and no soul.  The drinks were $10.00 and higher, the food is blah at best and random indie music playing on the overhead stereo. I will never be back.

We stopped at Brocach for dinner one Saturday night after walking around the square and being met with long waits at several of our other dining options. Brocach had available seating and we jumped on the chance to avoid a wait.

Normally, the lack of a wait would make me nervous, but we went with it & I had heard good things about Brocach in the past. I shouldn't have worried, though. The restaurant seemed to fill up within minutes of our arrival and there was a crowd of people waiting to be seated when we leave about an hour later.

Enough about the wait or lack of it - on to the food! My husband was "starving", so we got an order of lounge fried immediately. SO GOOD. Although how can fries smothered in melted cheese + bacon be bad? Yep, it can't. I ordered a salad and a cup of potato leek soup for my meal. The soup was delicious, the salad was just ok.

My husband ordered Bangers & Mash at the recommendation of our server. He really enjoyed it. I tried a bite too, and LOVED the added sweetness from the apples. He also ordered a couple of drinks, and enjoyed the large & creative drink menu.
Hours are wrong, poor service.  Decent food.

Really disappointed in this place. Walked in around 8pm at night looking to sit down for an hour or two and make travel plans. I was planning on having a few beers and maybe some food.

I walk in with my friend, both of us nicely dressed and not at all sketchy, and the server walks up to us and says "excuse me, our kitchen closes at 8pm and our bar closes soon. The other server looked confused and said we close at 11. The third server/bartender looks at us and says oh we close at 9pm. It was really awkward and we were just standing there. They clearly wanted us not to sit in their establishment and buy their products.

Would not step foot in this Brocach again.

So the remodel is done, everyone.  Whitewashed brick walls.  Booths, tables, and chairs are beautifully crafted wood pieces.  There is ironwork all around.   The upstairs looks like the downstairs.  The stairwell to upstairs as switched to the entrance side of the space.  The first and second floors are completely sealed off so that might mean no more noise bleeding from upstairs or down.  I do find the space beautiful.  I'm sure I will enjoy coming here as much as I did the old space.  But I have to admit I missed the warm colors and plush seats.  If the food is good, I can get over it.

My group of friends visited on a bright sunny Farmer's Market Saturday.  One of the out of towners had loved Brocach's when she lived here, so we were happy to find it open.  At our table, we ordered the Mussels, 2 Fish and Chips, 2 Bangers and Mash, and the Rachel sandwich.  Everyone reported everything was very good.  I found my fish's breading to be a bit soggy.  I hope it was just do to the new re-opening.  The Mussels dish was the only one I had not tried in the past and the flavor was really good.  The broth uses Guinness and it's a winner.

I hope to upgrade my stars as the new kitchen gets their footing and the crowds come back.

Good place for drinks not much else. 

Trust me, the Irish aren't known for food for a reason. I've lived in Cork. But I'm guessing even the Irish would prefer something else.

Didn't get to try the beer... I was being cheap that night, and the company I was interviewing for wouldn't cover alcohol expenses.

Scotch eggs were seemingly expensive for what they are ($4.50 for one soft-boiled egg wrapped in a thin layer of sausage and deep-fried). But the BBQ fries were great (like nachos except on a bed of fries instead of chips!), and the Irish stew made with Guinness was really great. Wish I had the recipe!

Greeted immediately, specials recited.  My friend had the fish and chips, which she said was great, although she didn't share with me.  I had the Reuben.  The waiter said that the corned beef was very lean, which it was - but it was dry and very stringy, and kind of tough.  Pleasant atmosphere, very good service.

Cold as hell and overly sweet would sum up my brunch experience today.   I wouldn't say I had a stellar first time at Brocach.  It was literally the coldest restaurant I've been in-we had a group of 18 people and every single person was unimpressed with the temperature of the restaurant.  If you have a warehouse of a restaurant, you really should be prepared to ensure your customers are not wearing their coats while eating.  Additionally, by the time food gets to your table, its cold too.  No one seemed to complain because I'm guessing at that point, we'd burned so many calories shivering that we were desperate to eat.  

I ordered the carrot and ginger soup-thank goodness they forgot to charge me for it because it was so sweet that I seemed to be able to taste the sugar granules.  I'm not interested in food that a restaurant has to make so sweet that you can't taste any other flavors.  My quiche was huge...quantity over quality.  The crust was soggy and really just not very good.  The salad had a dressing that seemed to be sprinkled with sugar dressing.  

The servers were nice and the restaurant itself is beautiful but that was about it.
Try the Bangers and Mash...they make it with an apple sauce that is really good!

Came here for a party upstairs and had a good time.  I was really impressed with the ambiance of the upstairs, the furniture however looked nasty.  I don't want to think of everything that happened on those sofas over the last 40 years.
We just had some appetizers which were good and the service was very friendly.  I think it is a good location for a big get together.  They let us take over the tv and music and were very patient and kind.

Visited Brocach on a Friday with high hopes for their Friday Fish Fry, and despite a small letdown, it was great!

Online, Brocach on the Square advertises their Friday Fish Fry Special as  the "Traditional Wisconsin Fish Fry: choose baked or fried cod, choice of potato (hand-cut fries, Colcannon mash or baked sweet), rye bread, house-made tartar". The part about this description that had me hooked was the option to have a baked sweet potato as my side. I LOVE sweet potatoes, and man oh man a baked sweet tater sounded so amazing with my fish. Well....... turns out, they don't have sweet potatoes to serve baked at Brocach. Womp. I was super bummed, but still stuck with the Fish Fry and tried the Colcannon mash instead. 

So anyways, we ate at the bar, had friendly service, and the food arrived after 20 minutes or so. The fish fry was so good! I wasn't so sad that they didn't have the sweet potato after trying the Colcannon mash - mmmmm yep it was good. Had green onions in it and the skin from the potatoes, and maybe more? Not sure, but it was tasty. I opted for the baked fish, which was good and they gave me three pieces. The coleslaw was super tasty too! And the rye bread was perfectly toasted and so soft. Overall, a wonderful meal that filled me up but didn't leave me feeling overstuffed and yucky like some fish fry's do to me. 

I would definitely return to Brocach for a fish fry, and I know it's on my list of places to go when I'm looking for some yummy Irish dishes!

HOLY SMOKES the burger was HUGE. I had to take a break in between bites to regain my composure before digging in again.
It was our first time in an Irish place but we weren't too adventurous. The Hail Mary although big, wasn't our fav Madison burger. 
Spinach and artichoke dip (see my pic) was really generous and we were totally filled up on that before the burger even arrived! That is a "must order" if you go!

Friday's are great here. No need to wait late for the music as the band fires up about 5:30 strumming, singing, piping and thumping away to the emjoyment of the usually packed crowd. I'd put a sample here on Yelp, but no video upload capability on Y.

You may have to wait for a table, but no worries as you'll get to be even closer ear to the musix going on in the bar area.

The usual beverages are here with Happy Hour til 6pm.

I liked the Wedge House Sirloin Salad.

Cooked to order, it arrived a nice medium rare. The wedge is amply sized and drizzled wth a blue cheese then a slight French dressing.¬†

Delicious and perfectly portioned.

Great little pub! The decor made me feel like I was sitting in a pub in the UK. The menu offers traditional British pub fare with a Wisconsin twist. Our very friendly server recommended the burgers and they were delicious.  I truly enjoyed my meal and the service. The Ginger Old Fashioned was a fantastic cocktail!

What a great place for lunch or dinner. Wonderful beer and cocktail selection. The ginger and Jameson specialty cocktail they have is to die for! We visited for lunch and I got the black bean burger which was wonderful...you can't go wrong with a pretzel bun. But I have to say my friend won for best meal. She got the pulled pork sandwich which is incredible. The meat is shredded nicely and is no tender plus it comes with sweet potato fries...GET THE SWEET POTATO FRIES!  Overall the atmosphere was wonderful (however it does get SUPER crowded in the evening) and service was very pleasant. Every time I come to Madison from St. Louis I always end up here and I am sure I will be back. The only reason I left a star off is that the cocktails are great but overall a little pricey compared to other establishments around town.

The food was excellent and our large party enjoyed the variety of beers on tap. As a vegetarian, I had many options, two of which proved to be delicious: the potato leek soup and the cheddar melt. Our waitress, Tasha, was pretty rude though. I'm guessing she ignored us and gave us terrible service because she knew she was guaranteed the 18% for our group of 8 or more.

I want this place to be great because it's so convenient to my house, and my kids like it.  But it's not great.  I ordered my daughter a brunch off the kids menu:  egg and cheese scrambler with whole wheat toast and a side of fruit.  What came was an egg and cheese scrambler with white toast and a heaping helping of fried potatoes.  Our waiter was perfectly nice about it -- when I asked her about the fruit, she looked at the menu, agreed it was supposed to come with fruit, and brought out a plate of fruit.  And when I asked her about the toast, she brought out some whole wheat toast.  Still, it's troublesome when what's brought out is different in so many ways from the dish on the menu.

The reviewer who described the breakfasts as capable of feeding 3-4 people must have had very small people in mind.  The eggs Benedict I got today was a single half-muffin, one poached egg, one slice of ham.  That the brunch filled me up at all was due to yet another large pile of fried potatoes.  They were good!  But a brunch of fried potatoes with a side of eggs benedict was not what I had in mind.   

The place was almost empty, but after waiting a while I had to get up and walk to the bar in order to get my coffee refilled.

If the food were great, all this stuff would be no problem.  And the food isn't bad!  But it's ordinary.  The quality is about the same as at Mickie's Dairy Bar, the greasy spoon up the street -- but Mickie's gives you twice as much ordinary food at half the cost.  Which I guess is why they're always full and we were one of only three tables eating at Brocach.

I'll have a Guinness, please.

This place is great. I love the fact that you can come here and be social and chat up new friends, or stick to the blokes you came in with. The main-level bar area has always seemed to me to be more conducive to socializing among the crowd, whereas the bar upstairs has seemed less so. And, if you're really looking to isolate your crew from the crowd, there are plenty of large (high-backed) booths to choose from too.

I imagine if there's any bar in town where you can get a Guinness mixed drink that goes beyond the clich√© Black & Tan, this would be the place.

The one thing that really needs the management's attention is the one-holer men's room. I'm not sure about the ladies facilities, but it's got to be the most awkward men's room I've ever used.

Now, about that Guinness?

The food is always serviceable, the service is generally good, and one of my favorite drinks can be found here.

Although it's not an Irish concoction, Brocach serves something called the Stoli Doli. Basically it's a martini made from vodka which has pineapple soaking in it all day. I was a patron of Capital Grill in Washington, DC - home of the original Stoli Doli. I like to hit Brocach occasionally when I am feeling nostalgic for my time there.

Brocach can be a little cramped, but usually it's a good time. I've certainly enjoyed myself at the various private events I've attended upstairs.

Let me say that in the beginning, way, way back, Brocach was excellent.  We just stopped in earlier this evening for dinner and wow, what a terrible change.  Brocach is no more an Irish Pub than McDonalds is a 3 star Michelin restaurant.  Like everything else downtown it has been gentrified, catering to the yuppie wannabes that inhabit the downtown of Madison these days.

The menu is decidedly crap.  The couple of dishes that are named after traditional Irish fare are nothing close to the real deal.  Aside from the menu having been butchered and cut down to about 1/4 of its original size it offers nothing that cannot be found within a few blocks in any direction.  We were so disgusted with the choices (hamburger on an English Muffin?  Really?) we just went for the fish and chips.  Our daughter went for shepherds pie off of the kiddie menu.

The fish was nothing great.  We've had better elsewhere to be sure.  What dug at me was that there were no condiments on the tables.  Apparently you get what they feel you should have in terms of simple things like ketchup, which comes in a tiny little plastic dish.  My daughter hated the shepherds pie.  I switched with her and she was right to hate it.  Terrible.  I've been making shepherds pie for over thirty years (if it has beef and not lamb, it's cottage pie, by the way Brocach) from a recipe my grandparents brought over.  I know a thing or two about Irish fare and none of this garbage was it.  I may be Irish American, but I am all Irish, and what we experienced tonight was nothing Irish.  It was Madison Yuppie/Hipster cuisine served up in a faux pub setting.

If you think you know Irish food, or what an Irish pub actually is, but in truth know nothing about it then by all means head to Brocach.  You can enjoy a completely false perspective on both.  However, if you are looking for real Irish food, in a real Irish setting (painting gaelic phrases on a wall does not an Irish Pub make), run as far away from Brocach as you can.  It's am embarrassment to all things Irish.

We will not be returning.  There is nothing authentic about the place.  The atmosphere is just Wisconsin Boozehound, like every other tavern in the state, not at all Irish.  This is an example of the need to have laws prohibiting places from naming themselves Irish Pub, Greek Tavern, Italian Restaurant, etc... when they are so far from the real thing they should be embarrassed.

If you want to hit a real Irish Pub, you need to head to Chicago or New York or Boston for a spot-on experience.  Note that you will only find these places in the crappy parts of town.  No self-respecting Irish Pub will be on a posh neighborhood.  Better yet, go to Ireland.

Just don't go to Brocach.

CORNED BEEF HASH. 

It is good and you should get it. 

The slow cooked corned beef, caramelized onion, and house potatoes are all just beautiful. Add some egg whites, wheat toast and asparagus and life is good.

We went to Brocach's during the last day of restaurant week and were seated right away!  I had the Beer Cheese burger and it was really good!  The atmosphere was fun and it wasn't too loud to hold a conversation.  There's a ton of delicious sounding food on the menu, so we'll definitely be back!

Appetizers
Buffalo wings: 4.5 stars, sauce was on point
Clam Chowder: 5 stars
Drinks:
Black Barrel Old Fashion: 4.5, quality and strong, would be a 5 @ $8
Main Courses:
Roasted Half Chicken: 3 stars, Chicken was dry
Smoked Salmon starter: 4 stars, little cold, bread was too soft

Bad service, bad atmosphere, mediocre food. It would be great to a have a nice Irish pub in Madison. Perhaps Cooper's Tavern on the square fits that bill, but Brocach on Monroe definitely does not. I don't know how this place is in business. If you are in the area do yourself a favor and go to Brasserie V down the street, much better food and service, plus an impressive beverage selection.
This place was cool and comfy prior to the remodel, now it's stark and just blah. They ruined the charm of one of the coolest places to eat in Madison. The food is good though!
Decent Irish brunch. Best thing about the place is that there aren't any long queues.. but then it might be a bad thing.. I kinda liked it

Decent enough spot for afternoon drinks and apps. Grabbed a spot at the bar easily enough on a Saturday afternoon. Decent draft beer selection, as well as craft cocktails. Tried a Bloody while we were there...one of the better made Mary's I've had. Partook in a scotch egg as well... Decent flavor but a tad dry. Presentation was solid, and the pickled onions and greens salad paired very well. Might not be our first stop during a Madison visit, but will most likely be on the itinerary. Not many places like it downtown, and the food menu begs for subsequent visits. PS solid bar service!

Faux-exposed brick?  Fuck you, Brocach.  Small menu but the food's pretty decent.

update: I can't get an appertizer at 4 PM?  As the kids say "omgwtf?!"

My husband and I started out with the beer cheese dip appetizer.  It was delicious.  It was 4 generous pieces of amazing pretzel bread accompanied by slices of bell peppers and carrot sticks.  The beer cheese dip was great...I maybe could have used just a little bit more though...we ate every last bit of the dip.  For dinner, my husband order the corned beef and cabbage entree.  After insisting to him that I do not like corned beef, he finally got me to try it.  I bet he wishes he wouldn't have...because after that I was sneaking bits of meat off his plate for the rest of the meal.  It had so much flavor and it almost melted in my mouth because it was so tender.   I would highly recommend trying it!   I ordered the shepherd's pie which was also delicious.  It's the perfect comfort food...meat and veggies topped with delicious mashed potatoes.  It's a very hearty meal, and I thoroughly enjoyed my leftovers the next day.

They also had live music which was very nice.

We stopped here for lunch on a Saturday and had a great meal and above average service by our waitress.  My dining companion and I split the Beer Cheese dip and it was delicious!  It is warm, smooth and creamy, and has just the right amount of heat.  It is served with some soft, warm pretzels and some raw carrots and red peppers.  Had I been alone, I could have made a meal from this.  We both had a cup of potato leek soup, that was also very good and it comes with a warm brown bread muffin, made in house.  We were already full after that but wanted to try an entree, so we asked to split the fish and chips.  Our waitress brought it out split evenly on two separate plates.  It was a nice surprise as we had expected to split it ourselves.  The fish and fries were both hot, crisp and tasty.  I did not try the coleslaw because by then I was just too full.  The decor is warm and beautiful, and our waitress was very personable without being overbearing.  She gets an A+ for keeping my water glass full.  

I was a little surprised at some of the prices, but that would be my only criticism.  Burgers are $12 and our lunch fish and chips was $14.  It seems a little pricey, but the quality of the food is good.  Oh wait...one more thing...the paint job in the restroom is a little disturbing, looks like a blood bath took place, I was not a fan.

Today at Brocach was a total miss.  My boyfriend ordered the poutine with corn beef which came out so cold the cheese curds didn't melt into the fries.  Corn beef had great flavor though.  I ordered the crab cake eggs benedict.  It was served barely warm and one of the crab cakes was about half the size of the other one.  I later ordered a pancake from the menu and was told they took pancakes off the menu. When I asked why they were still on the menu if they weren't offering them anymore the server checked with the kitchen and they made the pancake.  I was grateful but when the pancake was served it was half their normal size.  Don't know what was up with Brocach today but they had the B or C Team working the kitchen.

Surprisingly good! The folks I was with loved the Irish plates. I had the hamburger that had huge flavor!

Worth a try if your on the Madison square!!

Great Irish pub in Madison.  Love the decor inside and out in the front patio. You don't feel like you're in Madison anymore. 
Excellent fish and chips here, BUT I have noticed that over the years, the portions for fish and chips have gotten smaller.  It makes me want to come only on the days when they serve all you can eat fish and chips. I think, Fridays???

The roast chicken is another one of my favorites at Brocach. yum.

If you want something on the healthier side, order the greek salad with chicken.

I usually have nothing but good experiences when going to Madison and finding places to eat but this is one we won't be coming back to. I recall this location being a much more friendly place but I'm not sure if it's new ownership over the last few years, whatever it is... not good. The environment is not welcoming, prices are way too high for what you get, food is terrible and I could go on and on. I'll just say this, don't bother going here. They don't play the local games if something from Boston is on at the time.

I had my wedding after party at Brocach and while I had a fabulous time, I unfortunately cannot provide a good review of the venue. 

1) The music was inaudible and they would not turn up the music even after several requests and promises to do so.
2) Even though bar close is listed as 2am (on Yelp) and we still had dozens of people present, they closed the bar around midnight on a Saturday.
3) There was some confusion about tip being included on our bar tab and even though the general manager Marcos Jimenez assured us repeatedly that we could get reimbursed he has been non-responsive to e-mails and phone calls and we have not received the reimbursement more than a month later.

We loved the location on the square and the upstairs area is free to reserve and quite spacious. We had a great time despite the annoyances listed above but would definitely not recommend it for the above reasons. if Marcos ever follows through with issue #3 we'd consider increasing our rating to two or three stars.

Noise level on a busy Friday night is definitely NOT quiet. We ordered the fish fry which was good. Unfortunately we substituted an extra portion of cole slaw for the fries (chips). The fish was served on a mountain of cole slaw, tart with vinegar. Next time I'll just eat the chips and have a great meal. We will go back for the great ambiance and service.

We stopped in from the Dane County Farm Market for brunch.  Great food, surprising for an Irish pub.  In spite of its location on the square, it was not busy, we were seated immediately, and service was excellent.
